task.title: Starting the Engine in Cold Weather
task.shortdesc: Learn how to properly start and warm up your engine in cold weather conditions to ensure optimal performance and prevent stalling.

context.p: In cold weather, gasoline does not vaporize easily, making engine starts more challenging. Follow these procedures to start your engine effectively in cold conditions.

step.info: Turn the carburetor dash adjustment one-quarter turn to the left to enable a richer gasoline mixture.

substep.cmd: Either turn the crank six to eight quarter-turns in quick succession or turn the motor over several times using the starter

step.info: Hold out priming rod while turning the crank several times or using the starter

substep.cmd: Place spark lever in third notch

step.cmd: Start the engine by either giving the crank one or two turns or closing the starting switch

ul.li: Advance the spark eight to ten notches on the quadrant
Allow motor to run until thoroughly heated
Turn carburetor adjustment back one-quarter turn once warmed up

taskbody.result: The engine should start and run smoothly in cold weather conditions. Do not start driving with a cold motor, as you will have reduced power and may stall.
taskbody.postreq: For overnight storage, you may stop the engine by pulling out the priming rod, which fills cylinders with rich gasoline vapor. Only use this method if the car will stand long enough to cool off completely. Do not use this method if you plan to restart the engine while it's still hot, as it may cause starting difficulties.
